Trivia.text: Did you know? Since the Saving Our Blue campaign started, approximatley 16 tonnes tonnes of waste was collected from the sea and shorelines through beach, land, and dive cleanups.
Did you know that cigarettes contain plastic?
Did you know? The slogan for Saving Our Blue is “Be part of the SOLUTION, not the POLLUTION!”
Did you know that Marine Protected Areas protect marine biodiversity?
Did you know? Fishing is allowed only in a sustainable manner within Marine Protected Areas.
Interesting fact! The main threats to Marine Protected Areas are environmental pollution, trawling, and habitat degradation caused by humans.
Did you know? The Environment and Resources Authority is the leading authority on Marine Protected Areas.
Did you know? Using less single-use plastics makes a successful Marine Protected Area.
Interesting fact! Marine sanctuaries require strict protection, with limited human activity, to ensure the preservation of marine ecosystems.
Interesting fact! By the end of 2023, there were 18 different Marine Protected Areas around the Maltese Islands.
Did you know? Marine Protected Areas in the Maltese Islands are 4,100 km squared in size.
Interesting fact! Plastic litter found in the sea can harm fish and birds, as plastic stays in their stomachs, making it difficult for fish to digest food.
Did you know? Ghost nets are abandoned fishing nets that can trap fish and turtles, posing a serious threat to these creatures.
You can help to preserve Marine Protected Areas by responsibly separating and disposing of waste.
Did you know? The term single-use plastics refers to any plastics designed for one-time use, typically intended to be discarded or recycled after a single use.
The littering of single-use plastics have a heavy impact on Marine Protected Areas.
Did you know? Malta banned the selling  and distribution of plastic straws in 2022
Interesting fact! A textile bag is a better alternative to plastic shopping bags.
Did you know? Cigarette butts are the most common littered item found on beaches.
Did you know? If we don't change our plastic consumption habits, it's projected that by 2050, there will be more plastic in the oceans than fish.
Did you know? The equivalent of a garbage truck's worth of plastic waste is dumped into the ocean every minute.
Interesting fact! Approximately, 8 million tonnes of plastic end up in the world's oceans every year.
Did you know? In 2022, a ban was introduced on the distribution and sale of certain single-use plastic items in Malta.
Did you know? Single-use plastic plates are among the items included in the single-use plastic distribution and sale ban list of prohibited single-use plastics.
Did you know? Polystyrene cups are among the items that were prohibited.
Did you know? Plastic cotton buds are among the items that were prohibited in the Maltese Islands.
Did you know? Takeaway food containers made of polystyrene are banned in the Maltese Islands.
Did you know? Bamboo straws are more sustainable because they can be used over and over again.
Did you know? Malta has a Strategy intentioned to bring about a behavioural shift within society in terms of its attitude toward single-use plastics.
Did you know? Single-use plastic cutlery is harmful to the environment?
Did you know? Malta's Single-Use Plastics Strategy, 'Rethink Plastic,' covers the period from 2021 to 2030.
Interesting fact! Malta's Single-Use Plastics Strategy 'Rethink Plastic' contains a number of measures that aim at reducing the consumption of certain single‑use plastic products.
Did you know? By 2030, all plastic packaging in the EU should be designed to be recyclable or reusable.
Fun fact! An aim of Malta's Single-Use Plastics Strategy 'Rethink Plastic' is to increase the quality and quantities of single-use plastic waste collected for recycling.
Did you know? A Green Consumer is a customer who wants to buy things that have been produced in an environmentally friendly way with the intention to protect the environment.
Did you know? The Loggerhead turtle is a protected marine species.
Did you know? Sea urchins have a spiky outer shell.
Did you know? The Bottlenose dolphin, Loggerhead turtle and Neptune seagrass are all found in Maltese waters.
Interesting fact! The largest estimated Mediterranean Storm-Petrel breeding colony can be found in Filfla, Malta.
